reviewText: Finally, at long last this great cult classic has been re-released, this time on DVD. For decades, the movie was virtually impossible for fans and collectors to obtain except either as a rental tape or very rarely for purchase as a beat-up, ex-rental VHS tape (which typically sold for an exorbitant price if it could be found in that format at all). After languishing in movie distribution red tape literally for decades, it was finally slated for release on DVD in the fall of 2009 by Image Entertainment. Unfortunately, that release was scratched at the last minute because of some additional legal or distribution snafu.Now, after the 2009 false start it's finally here for real, released in September, 2010 just in time for Halloween (this time by VCI Entertainment) and in a great new, spiffy-looking restoration on DVD. Originally released as a CBS made-for-TV movie in 1981, this movie is one of two which I consider to be quintessential Halloween movies (the other is the great 1978 movie,  "Halloween" by John Carpenter, which I think is in a class by itself and is probably now considered one of the top horror movies ever made)."Dark Night of the Scarecrow" may not be quite up to the exceptional quality of "Halloween" but it doesn't miss it by all that much. While it wasn't written by Stephen King, it reminds me of some of his best works, such as "Christine" and "Salem's Lot" in form, style, plot and overall quality (but with less gore). Also, it has the look and feel of a story set in New England (where some of King's most spooky stories take place), even though it is actually set in the California country side, just north of Los Angeles. While the movie is great viewing at any time during the year, its spooky atmosphere (which is high on terror but mercifully light on gore) and harvest time theme make it perfect for viewing on or near Halloween.I will leave the plot details to others. I find that too many plot details ahead of time tend to spoil the viewing pleasure of many movies for me and I am sure that many others feel the same. There are plot synopses available elsewhere on Amazon and also on movie sites for those who are interested. Suffice it for me to say that it is a story of intolerance, hate, stupidity and most of all, terror. The story gives new meaning to the term "payback is a bummer (insert your own word here)" and the fun is in watching it unfold.The acting is great throughout. Larry Drake turns in a superb performance as a handicapped adult with the emotional age of about 8-9 yrs. It reminded me of Cliff Robertson's Oscar winning performance as a mentally retarded man in the movie "Charly". The veteran character actor Charles Durning is deliciously odious as the movie's villain, one who oozes detestability from every pore and earns the viewer's complete contempt.The DVD itself contains a number of extras including optional commentary by the writer, J.D. Feigelson and the director, Frank De Felitta, either optional 5.1 surround sound or regular stereo sound, and optionally both Spanish and English subtitles. As I mentioned before, the print has been fully restored and looks absolutely terrific on DVD. It looks crisp and bright and I didn't find it lacking in any respect at all. Since the movie was originally made for TV, there is no widescreen version. It is of course only available in full screen.Finally, those who appreciate fine movies owe their everlasting gratitude to those who labor to make hard to find movies such as this one available to the public. They make it a cause to restore and/or re-release these hidden gems which for one reason or another either never before made it to home video at all or were available at one time but were withdrawn because of distribution right problems. More and more of them are finally starting to make it to DVD as this welcome and overdue release proves. "Dark Night of the Scarecrow" is a terrific bargain, especially at current prices. Since one never knows how long any specific movie will remain in print and available these days (particularly ones such as this one with its history of extensive legal wrangling), grab it while you can.
summary: A Gem Has Finally Been Released on DVD!

reviewText: I was so pleasantly surprised when I saw this movie. I had heard about it for years, but had never been able to track it down anywhere. I finally saw it. This is not your typical Made For T.V. movie. It is surprisingly chilling, creepy, and violent. I was really shocked, but delighted. This movie originally aired in 1981. Charles Durning stars as a small town postal worker who, along with some local resident friends, have been looking for ways to get rid of a local mentally retarded man named Bubba, who is played by Larry Drake. When a little girl is hurt and Bubba is the prime suspect, that's all the motive that the small vigilante group needs to go after them. They kill Bubba by shooting him 21 times. The four men go to court but are aquitted due to lack of evidence. This is where it gets weird. The four men then begin to be stalked. They see a ratty old scarecrow(where Bubba was hiding from them and killed in) appear in their pastures. Out of nowhere. The four guilty men then begin to pay for their horrible actions. In a way, this has the same kind of idea of the movie "I Know What You Did Last Summer". Keeping a secret that eventually comes to bite you in the rear. The director knows how to set up the chills and tension. Things get dark and shadowy. Very eerie. This guy definitley took some notes from the original "Halloween". You never really see who the killer is and or see him do the kills. It's all implied. It would've been nice to see a glimpse or two of the killer, like in "The Blair Witch Project", where again, it was implied. You do in the very end and it's a little odd. Charles Durning does a great job as postal worker Mr. Hazelrig. He definitley goes nuts and you believe it. The other familiar face here is Lane Smith, who played Perry White on "Lois And Clark". Drake as Bubba can put another weird character on his list of weird characters. That is all he plays. This movie will surprise you. It has nice set pieces, and moments that are visually eerie and creepy. It is a lost, overlooked little gem of a thriller. If only T.V. movies of today had enough balls to make them like this again. That would be a real joy.

reviewText: This is one of my favorite horror movies.  I'm not a big horror film fan.  Why?  It is because Hollywood turns out mainly garbage masquerading as "horror" movies.  This film defies the Hollywood trend by proving that good movies don't need sex, gore, nudity, cussing, drug use, special effects and a boat load of teenagers. It scares you more with things that you don't see.  I loved it.  The story happens in a rural small town.  A young girl is mauled by a dog, but is saved by her friend Bubba.  Bubba is a harmless Downs Syndrome adult, who is loathed by many of the locals, who are ignorant bigots.  A group of these guys quickly (mistakenly) think that Bubba is the one who attacked the girl.  To protect him, his mother disguises him as a scarecrow out on their farm.  Unfortunately, the gun toting bigots figure this out and they gun him down whilst he is propped up in his scarecrow outfit.  Shortly after this event, one by one, each of those who take part in this murder are mysteriously killed in horrible ways.  Who is doing it?  I wont say, you will have to see the film.  It also sports a great ending that tops off this movie perfectly.  See it, you wont be disappointed.  That is, unless your idea of a good horror movie is Saw III or Hostel. Ugh!

reviewText: The seminal scarecrow classic makes its long-awaited DVD debut with a beautifully remastered transfer care of VCI Entertainment! Originally premiering on CBS as a made-for-TV movie, this brilliantly-crafted revenge film shares as much in common with Hitchcockian suspense thrillers as it does with the early 80's Slashers of its time, minus the gratuitous gore. DARK NIGHT OF THE SCARECROW finds the simpleminded Bubba on the run from an unruly mob after he is falsely accused of killing a young girl. The four vigilantes find Bubba hiding in an empty field dressed as a scarecrow, and ruthlessly murder him before finding out that he was innocent of the crime. Now, Bubba has come back for revenge, donning the burlap mask and pitchfork that he was left to die in! Film legends Charles Durning and Lane Smith headline as the town baddies in two of their most admirable performances. Unlike FRIDAY THE 13th or MY BLOODY VALENTINE of the same year, DARK NIGHT OF THE SCARECROW provides all of the same gruesome murders and without spilling even a single drop of blood, tastefully cutting away from the actual event while implying the worst. Director Frank de Filetta delivers a steady stream of chilling suspense, teasing the audience with scarecrow calling cards that are left in distant fields to intimidate Bubba's killers while foreshadowing who will be the next to die. The most terrifying moment comes in the film's thrilling climax, where Bubba stalks his final victim through a foggy pumpkin patch on Halloween night. DARK NIGHT OF THE SCARECROW is not only an excellent Slasher movie, but also one of the strongest made-for-TV Horror films of all-time, and VCI has gone to great lengths to provide the definitive release that fans have been demanding for decades!-Carl ManesI Like Horror Movies

reviewText: This is probably the best horror TVM ever made in the US, and that's not an idle claim. Everything about this fillum - the casting, acting, scripting, photography & direction - exudes quality.Charles Durning's performance as Otis Hazelrigg is pivotal to the success of the story and he gives one heck of good turn. His descent into ever more warped logic, dragging his co-conspirators along, and even more desperate acts as the fillum progresses is absolutely rivetting to watch. It could so easily have been overdone - a middle aged batchelor postman living in a boarding house, snooping on peoples' mail, with a dark behavioural secret [it is hinted at that Hazelrigg is known by some to be dangerous around children, to put it tactfully], handing out his own brand of redneck mob justice... BUT both the writing and the acting take these elements and conbime them subtlely for a compelling, believable and unnerving experience.The pacing is surprisingly good for a TVM and the use of cleverly composed shots and implication of gory / violent death, rather than the vivid depiction of it [remembering that TV was far more censorial than fillum] are effectively and powerfully used.There are some really nice twists of ironic 'justice', and scares too - the titular scarecrow appearing in the murderers' fields, marking them out for death, is a superb recurrent motif. In the finale there is even, what appears to be, a 'nod' to the 1974 TVM Killdozer, as a very large piece of driverless farm machinery pursues the breathless Hazelrigg across a pumpkin field to his brilliantly staged death.Perhaps the only minor detraction in the whole thing is the revelation, at the very end, that the Scarecrow is 'alive' and probably personally / physically accountable for things like switching on the woodchipper, or frightening the grain mill owner to the point of locking himself in the silo, rather than Bubba's disembodied energy coming back from beyond the grave to create the circumstances of the deaths AND using the Scarecrow merely as a totem to frighten the murderers, which is the suggestion that runs throughout the fillum until the final twist, and I feel that inference was far more effective than having a Wizard of Oz style stick figure lolloping about carrying out revenge on Bubba's behalf - acting as his earthly agent.As to the DVD, utterly superb in every way - the packaging, the print itself, have never looked better, AND this DVD is actually REGION FREE meaning it can be played without issue by English viewers such as myself.
summary: Probably the best US horror TVM of all time

Now in court the 4 men lie and say that Bubba attacked them with a pitchfork which is a lie. One of the 4 men also kill Bubba's mother. Each man who has committed the deed begin to die off. reviewText: This might be one of the best made-for-TV movies ever. It is a developed story of mob violence and revenge with some round (rather than flat) characters. In a small farm town, a group of vigilantes spread nasty rumors about a harmless but misunderstood adult man with mental disabilities named Bubba (Larry Drake). When Bubba saves his friend's life from a dog attack, he is falsely accused of murdering her when she is mistaken as dead. A group of bigoted vigilantes led by the angry local post master (Charles Durning) chase Bubba, who is dressed in a creepy burlap scarecrow disguise, and attack him. The vigilantes escape prosecution thanks to a lack of evidence and prejudice in the community but Bubba's mother (Jocelyn Brando) and the local district attorney vow that justice will find them one way or the other. Strange things begin happening around town and one of the vigilantes who escaped justice swears he saw the scarecrow near his house. Is Bubba still alive or is someone plotting revenge on his behalf or is something supernatural occurring?This is an exception to the banality and mediocrity many television films succumb to, usually due to poor writing. The script of "Dark Night of the Scarecrow" is actually well crafted with a good dialogue and character development as well as some genuine mystery. The acting is well done, particularly Durning, whose vicious character is quite the louse and creep who gets very paranoid and panicky towards the end. The film lacks big scares and gore but it has a certain Hitchcockian feel to it and there are some creepy moments, particularly the camera's shots of Bubba's eyes in the ominous-looking scarecrow mask.This restored version of the film's print is really clear and great to see. It looks a lot better than the VHS release and there are some interesting features on the DVD including a documentary called "Bubba Didn't Do It!" and commentary by writer J.D. Feigelson. This film is not quite the perfect horror film of, say, John Carpenter's Halloween but it is rightfully a cult classic and worth seeing.

reviewText: I recently sat down and watched Dark Night of the Scarecrow for the first time in close to 30 years.  I was not disappointed.  This is one of the few films of its type that manages to transcend its made-for-TV roots, and can stand on its own as a highly competent shocker.  Fans of gore and mindless mayhem should probably pass this one by, as DNOTS derives its scares more from its early frightening scenes of blind persecution, to its later images of forboding, dread of the seemingly inevitable, and culminating in sheer stark terror.  The setting and atmosphere of the film is near perfect, and the acting, directing, and photography are all top notch.Perhaps my only disappointment with this film - and it is only a minor disappointment - is that most of the "kills" are very predictable - that is, they set up the premise as well as the scenario for each individual's demise early on, and more or less never deviate from that pattern.  You basically know exactly how each character is going to meet his end way before it actually happens. This is not due to my having seen the film nearly three decades ago, as I remember very little about it from back then.  Perhaps I'm simply too jaded from having watched countless other horror movies during the intervening years. But the writer and director should be commended for taking the high road with these scenes by keeping most of the actual deaths off-camera (though I'm sure the constraints of early '80's television had a great deal to do with that), relying on the concept of what you don't see can often be the most frightening.All in all, if you're looking for a good scary film you can watch on your own, or even as a family, Dark Night of the Scarecrow should fit the bill.  It's not fun, it's not campy - in fact, it's rather unsettling, and you may find yourself trying to explain to your kids what is perhaps the most frightening element of the film - the blind bigoted hatred spawned by ignorance displayed near the beginning that sets up the circumstances for everything that follows.  Sometimes it's hard to believe there are people out there like that, though of course there are many.  Probably a lot more now than there were in the early '80s.Now that's REALLY scary...
summary: Made-For-TV Thriller that Delivers the Goods

reviewText: Like many other movies, 'Dark Night of the Scarecrow' deals with an act of terrible injustice and its aftermath. As one might anticipate, the evildoers wind up facing retribution for their misdeed. This film combines elements of the traditional ghost story with the slasher motif of having a big, hulking killer going around wreaking havoc.Justice is dealt out in very efficient and brutal fashion.There is so much to like here. I mean, who doesn't enjoy seeing ignorant, mean-spirited hicks getting shredded? But, aside from that, this is one of the finest ghost stories I've ever seen. The story unfolds right around the Halloween season, and the holiday ambience permeates a great deal of the action. The movie has a very rural, agrarian, Middle-America feel to it. They manage to capture some of the idyllic harvest themes that we tend to associate with Autumn. There are moments in this film where you get the feeling that Ichabod Crane would have been right at home.But the film is not shy about exploring the more brutish side of human nature. An unfortunate person is bullied, harassed..........and finally murdered, basically because he made other people somewhat uncomfortable. And, among the villains, there are strong indications that the leader and Alpha male is a pedophile.So, for all the rustic autumn charm, and seasonal ambience, there is a decidedly coarse underbelly to this tale.Fields overflowing with pumpkins. Nocturnal trips to the graveyard. The little girl,all alone(?) in the field, singing in the dead of night. The vile mailman, who falsely impugns the town simpleton as a child molester, while all the while harboring his own lust for the girl in question. The brisk fall wind, which figures so heavily in some scenes that it almost seems like a character unto itself. The four 'friends' who begin to turn on each other at the first sign of trouble.And the scarecrow.He is depicted as about equal parts omen of doom, righteous avenger, and Michael Myers-style, harvest-season slasher. This was a tv movie, so the violence is largely implied. But they shroud the killer in mystery, choosing to reveal him primarily through the terrified reactions of his victims as he closes in.For me, this really works better than if they had made a point of showing him in an obvious fashion.I think modern filmmakers could learn a lot from the people who made this. reviewText: Over the course of my lifetime of growing up with and watching tv, there is remarkably little in the way of scary or sheer drama, terror, if you will, that has remained "memorable" in my mind.The first that I remember, and was "haunted by" was from a show called "Panic", and it involved a wife waking up, terrified, from a dream about her husband, a salesman on the road on a dark stormy night, ending up not where he was supposed to be, and going over the side of a cliff. Well, as it turns out, this dream actually plays out in real life for him! I was probably about 8 or 9 at the time, and I never forgot this show...bad dreams for weeks afterwards!There were series, of course, but these do not count as they were regular. The next time something like this scared the hell out of me was on Boris Karloff's "Thriller" when he presented Oscar Wilde's "Portrait of Dorian Grey", which years later I found out was an actual movie that had played in the theaters years before. This, too, scared the living crap out of me, leaving never-forgotten shivers!A third one, presented as three separate tales called "Trilogy of Terror" starred Karen Black, and one of those three stories was breathtakingly terrifying, and truly breath-stopping in its depiction of sheer horror, where an African voo-doo doll comes to life and relentlessly persues her with a brutality that even today makes me wonder how those scenes ever made it onto television! The final scene here is absolutely over-the-top chilling! Unfortunately, the other two tales don't come close to matching this portion of the film, leaving it rather episodic.And last, many fond memories are accorded this little "shocker", that I enthusiastically recommend and review here. This film is a living testament to just how good television "could be" but sadly is not!I remember this truly original, carefully thought out, wonderfully scary and spooky film from (can it really be) 30 years ago! It seems like yesterday, that's how well I have retained it because of its originality and clever denoument. It's "almost" and "questioning" end is absolute story-telling genius, not to be beaten, even in first rate theater presentations. This truly was, and still remains, one of television's "shining moments of greatness", and deserving of all the praise heaped on it here by these many 5-star reviews and raves from so many. It truly was original in its concept, and is the "daddy" of a whole genre of films and stories that followed it. Sadly of course, it is hardly known, either missed by many when it aired, or simply forgotten after all these years since.What a thrill, after such a long time of "remembering" it, to actually see this terrific film once again! It is one of a few films that I just love to show people and get their reactions! It is amazing how few people have ever seen it, even less heard about it! One satisfying aspect that I enjoy is everyone's enthusiastic praise for it, and their surprise that they had never heard about it considering how good it is! I don't recall anybody NOT being impressed with it and thoroughly entertained.Another reason why I am such a lover of "teaching" and such an avid film buff, and promoter of the world of "story on film" or perhaps better expressed as "visual story telling".The presentation here, incidentally, is first rate. Crystal clear image quality, and the sound is excellent. It easily hides its age, which means "kudos" to the folks at VCI for their excellent work remastering this for dvd.If you have not seen this film, I of course highly recommend it to you, as so many others do also. If you have seen it then you probably remember it clearly. If you do not, then by all means, do revisit it once again. It has not lost its edge, and remains as fresh and unique as it was the first time all those years ago!~operabruin

reviewText: A few years ago, TBS used to show this made for TV movie on Halloween named "Dark Night of The Scarecrow", which is a pretty darn good little ghost story.  The plot involves a severely retarded 35 year old man named Bubba, who has the mind of a 6 year old and he has a little girl as a friend who is about 7 or 8.  Well, things seem to be fine between the two, but when a dog attacks the little girl named Mary Lee, local beer bellies blame Bubba.  Rushing to judgement the men, led by Hazelrig played very well by Charles Durning, kill poor Bubba.Well, the men are able to elude the justice of the law but "there are other forms of justice on this earth" as Bubba's Mother said so well.  At any rate, a murder mystery and revenge theme develops and the men who killed Bubba are faced with a more formidable adversary than Bubba and they are forced to confront their own fears of something not of this world."Dark Night of The Scarecrow" does a good job making a scary little ghost story and as another reviewer has stated, the countryside makes a great setting for a scary movie.  It's hard to call "Dark Night of The Scarecrow" a "horror movie", but it is a little scary.  The only thing about this movie is that the ghost is apparently a good ghost and that reduces the level of fear in the audience.  Moreover, the audience sympathizes with Bubba and despise his killers which makes the ghost all the more endearing to the audience.  Hence, the element of "horror" is significantly compensated by this theme.The kills in "Dark Night of The Scarecrow" are interesting and creative...there is no gore, but the movie is quite effective without it.  The best part about "Dark Night of The Scarecrow" is that the story is so good.  Indeed, "Dark Night of The Scarecrow" is a solid ghost story dealing with revenge and justice.  The countryside setting and the farming equipment theme utilized in this movie work great to create a scary little atmosphere, creepy enough to satisfy the horror movie fan.I see a lot of high reviews for this movie and I agree wholeheartedly that this is a very underrated movie that deserves more recognition from the horror genre.  However, if I were to give the classic horror movie ratings of FIVE STARS to movies like: Halloween, The Shining, The Exorcist, The Omen, etc., etc., (movies which set the standard for horror movies) then, on that very same scale, I would have to give "Dark Night of The Scarecrow" 3.99 STARS which indicates a very effective ghost story movie.  That being said, I wouldn't put it up there with the classics or the elite movies that the horror movie genre has to offer, but it does play nicely on Halloween!Evidently, this movie is not out on DVD and that is a shame as it is one of the best ghost story movies ever made.  I recommend "Dark Night of The Scarecrow" as an underrated and fairly unrecognized ghost story movie to the horror movie fan and highly recommend it to people who enjoy ghost story movies and movies regarding the supernatural in general.
summary: 3.99 STARS: Chilly little revenge story with a supernatural flavor.

What follows is a revenge tale with spooky twists and turns that will have you wondering if the forces at work are human... or supernatural. All of the actors here turn in first rate work, and the movie definitely gets under your skin. I remembered the movie more than 20 years after first having seen it on TV, so it sure had an impact on me as a young teenager. Those were the days! reviewText: I'd like to state right off the bat and for the record that I am not, nor have I ever been, a "horror movie" fan. However, if every supposed "horror" picture were as well done as Dark Night of the Scarecrow, I may have to reconsider my position.What has become known as the modern type "slasher" horror film (with lots of gore, blood and guts) is to me just a bunch mindless nonsense that gives a quick  "thrill" to those with an unhealthy fixation for evil. The excellent made-for-tv movie "Dark Night of the Scarecrow" however, provides no such cheap thrills, taking instead a much different path. [--WARNING: Movie Spoiler Alert!--] The principal character of the film's title is not the mindless, killing psychopath stalking a bunch of over-sexed, teenage idiots that many such slasher/horror films depict. Instead, our "scarecrow" represents a subtle, otherworldly supernatural avenging force. A force which brings swift justice to the cowards who brutally murder an innocent man in cold blood. A very welcome change of pace for a supposed "horror" film. The "horror" is seen on the faces of the criminals fleeing for their lives! The script, directing and acting are all above-averge for a film of this type. So, if you like your "horror" bloodless (almost), intelligent, with a B-movie feel, and a Twilight-Zone twist, then be sure to check out JD Feigelson's Dark Night of the Scarecrow - you won't soon forget it.The Blu-ray edition has a nice assortment of extras including:- A full-length movie commentary with creator JD Feigelson (96 min.)- Bubba Didn't Do It! - 30 Years of the Scarecrow Documentary (30 min.)- DNOTS Cast Interviews with Larry Drake, Tonya Crowe and JD Feigelson (45 min.)- An 8-page booklet insert.- And More!

reviewText: "Dark Night of the Scarecrow" is the perfect Halloween movie for those who are fed-up with the over-the-top, ridiculous gore in fare like "Friday the 13th" or "Scream".This is a quiet little TV-movie from 1981 that has garnered somewhat of a cult following over the years from its annual reruns on cable stations like TBS.Charles Durning and a trio of small-town vigilantes execute the town simpleton Bubba Ritter (Larry Drake) after a young local girl named Marylee (Tonya Crowe) is hurt. They immediately learn that the mentally-challenged Bubba actually SAVED her life after a vicious dog attack. Though the judge declares them all innocent, Bubba's mother warns "There's other justice in this world besides the law!".A series of strange events makes each of the murderers gradually come unglued until Durning himself is convinced little Marylee is responsible for all the bizarre accidents that are offing his cronies.Though I like my horror movies to be based somewhat in reality, the ghostly and supernatural overtones of this movie didn't put me off at all.  It's a highly-entertaining ride all the way through that never lags or bores, despite the low-key ambiance of the whole thing.The visuals here are very interesting; Durning leers behind a skeleton decal on the window; wind blowing eerily through a dry wheat field; trash cans rolling through the street on a gusty night; the bright oranges and rusts of the pumpkin patch. All of these evoke a wonderful autumn atmosphere that makes this a Halloween classic.The director also uses several clever cuts like when one character falls to his death into a wood chipper he cuts to a dollop of strawberry preserves being plunked onto a dessert plate--brilliant! And never before has a silo looked so menacing or the piercing whistle of a kettle been used to such great effect to amplify the tension.The film is also surprisingly layered and subtle, as when we learn that Durning may have had another motive for killing Bubba--jealousy of his friendship with Marylee. Durning's stalking of the girl at the Halloween dance and Mrs. Ritter's insinuations of pedophilia visibly unnerve him and give the viewer more reason to despise him.The movie has an almost fable-like quality to it, about the pitfalls of paranoia, reaping what you sow and has not dated at all.There is also an ambiguity about Marylee's spiritual connection with Bubba and a creepy, ambiguous ending.**TRIVIA NOTE** Tanya Crowe (Marylee) was the actress who played the young Kelly Garrett/Jaclyn Smith in the famous "Seance" episode of "Charlie's Angels" where the wicked orphanage matron Beamish locks young Kelly in the closet.VCI Entertainment has done an exceptional job on this release. The print looks fabulous--as though it were filmed yesterday. Though most of their output so far has consisted of more Grindhouse-like horror movies, I commend them for doing such a great job in putting out the long overdue "Dark Night of the Scarecrow".

reviewText: A very pre-"Darkman" Larry Drake plays the adult-yet-childlike Bubba in this tale of merciless woodchippers, evil mailmen, mob justice and vengeance from beyond the grave.  Bubba is viewed with a mix of hatred and fear from the residents of his TV-style southern town.  His only friend is a young girl with whom he seems to be forming an unnatural bond.  His nemesis is a bigoted mailman played by Charles Durning, and his gold-old-boy crony, a farmer played by Lane Smith.  When the young girl is brutally attacked by a pitbull - apparently killed - suspicion falls on Bubba.  (Okay, so Bubba is the one seen carrying her blood-soaked "body" away.)  Faster than you can say ANOVELBYJOHNGRISHAM, Smith and Durning round up a posse to track down and kill Bubba.  In a scene that's funny, terrifying and heart-wrenching all at once (and also much better than a TV movie deserves to have) Durning and crew discover Bubba hiding as a scarecrow behind his mother's house.  It's only after the lynch mob has done its job that word comes in that it was all a big mistake - the girl wasn't killed at all, and it was Bubba who saved her.  Durning and company stand trial, but this is a TV southern jury, in a TV southern town.  When Bubba's killer's walk free, it turns to TV southern justice from beyond death to do what lawyers could not.  (Among other things, lawyers aren't allowed to stuff people into woodchippers or bury them in silos - but spectral justice knows nothing of such due-process technicalities.)  Is it really Bubba striking back?  And can anything stop his mad quest for revenge?This is one of those paradoxical movies of our 1970's youth - made for TV but more memorable than most feature films. Whether it's "Trilogy of Terror", "Gargoyles", "Salem's Lot" or this flick, we've watched them wondering the same thing: how did this make it to TV. And more importantly, how does a TV flick which looks like a TV flick manage to sustain such suspense? Who cares - this is simply one more underappreciated classic that hasn't been seen on screen for years (basic cable is too busy repeatedly running "I know what you did" movies), a relic of a time before disease of the week movies or those "inspired by an actual story".

reviewText: So who says you need a huge budget, a lot of computer generated special effects, and super big names to make an excellent horror film?I saw this originally back when it first aired on TV and have never forgotten it.  The screenplay is superb; I believe even Stephen King could not have done any better.  One is kept wondering throughout the film if a vengeful human--District Attorney, Bubba's mother, the little girl--might be exacting the justice that was denied in the courtroom.  The ending shot is almost poetic in both its simplicity and what it confides to us.  The director halts the film at that touching, if horrific moment, while the little girl's voice continues speaking to the Scarecrow as the credits roll.  It doesn't get any better then this.I have always found scarecrows to be unsettling at the least and a frightening parody of man at best.  Curiously, its origins actually stem back into ancient pagan religions.  Scarecrows actually do not scare crows, or other birds for that matter, due to the fact that they never move (except in the movies) and the animals become used to their presence.  In reality, they represent the ancient God of Fertility, and were put in fields as a supplication to this god for a bountiful harvest.  Few people today realize that when they put up this effigy, they are really worshiping an ancient deity.  Which, in my opinion, fits in nicely with the theme of supernatural revenge in this movie.There is also an unsettling thread throughout this movie and others like it (Dark Secret of Harvest Home comes to mind) of just what might be occurring in these small and isolated communities.  Seemingly almost out of touch with the modern world, Dark Night of the Scarecrow reminds us that anything is possible within an insular town, even murder and revenge.This is a classic that needs to be digitally re-mastered onto DVD, if someone hasn't thought of it already.  It is a refreshing change from the big blockbusters of today, and shows that imagination coupled with an outwardly innocent setting can produce a tale of pure horror.  Horror, yes, but with an ending that is curiously satisfying.  I could not think of a better way to end this grim little fairy tale from the depths of darkness.

reviewText: READ:  RUN to purchase this movie.  NOW!  You will thank me.  PROMISE.  Everyone says the same thing when I beg them to get this DVD: "OH MY GOD, THAT WAS SO [BLANK]ING SCARY!"  And, "BEST SCARY MOVIE OF ALL TIME!"  This is truly a masterful terror film worth major awards.... except Dark Night Of The Scarecrow was released a simple television movie.  Without question, though, it should have been a major theatrical release.  Because of production values in the late 1970's, at first, this movie comes across like a typical "B" horror flick of those days.  You can easily compare it to the creepy, weekly television episodes of "In Search Of..." [with Leonard Nimoy] which were released at the same time.  As it turns out, that 70's TV "look" and sound is what makes this film all the more unsettling and believable.  The cinematography is deliberately spooky with its sweeping, dreary landscapes, lone figures set against stark backgrounds, moody set designs and confusing use of light and shadows.  And just as important is the use of an INCREDIBLY eeeeeerrrrie soundtrack.  With its completely believable acting and a flawless, compelling storyline, Dark Night of The Scarecrow comes together like your favorite dish at your favorite restaurant.  You crave every moment of it.  This is a movie you want to watch over and over again just to see your friend's reactions.  Giving nothing away here, Dark Night of The Scarecrow is a clever, morbid fairy tale.  It is the unsettling story of how sweet revenge is played out.  And how it is played out in this movie is nothing short of delicious.  This film quickly becomes an edge-of-your-seat chiller that sets an uncomfortable and looming tone that leaves you shaken for the rest of the movie.  And thereafter.  Seriously.  It has been over thirty years and I STILL can NOT look at a scarecrow the same EVER AGAIN.  And I can NOT walk in open fields at night EVER AGAIN.  It's just that powerful!

reviewText: A dwindling supply of hard-to-find VHS copies had almost relegated this title to the realm of forgotten movies. That makes the release of this remastered and enhanced DVD cause for celebration among horror-fans new and old, as this classic tale of a vengeful spirit, while low budget, is a fine example of a horror film done right.Scarecrow was originally written for the screen but wound up being made for television instead, a fact that goes a long way toward explaining the almost total lack of gore and on-screen violence. Perhaps the relatively stringent restrictions of 80's network broadcasts is what ended up making this film as good as it is: To make up for the easy thrills and scares denied them by the censors the film makers had to focus on story, characters and atmosphere.Set in a small town and featuring a relatively short list of characters, Scarecrow centers around the slaying of the mentally handicapped Bubba by 4 townsmen led by postman Otis. Bubba, a 30 something year old man with the mind of a child, tends to make friends with the only people in town he can relate to: children. Otis and his compadres have been terrorizing the poor guy for years on the grounds that he is bound to try to take advantage of one of his playmates one day, but for the most part they just like beating on the village idiot. That changes when Bubba shows up carrying the savagely mauled body of the little girl he was playing with. Spurred on by Otis, the quartet shift gears into full vigilante mode. They hunt down Bubba, who has disguised himself as a scarecrow to avoid the mob, and execute him in cold blood.It isn't long before they learn that Bubba was innocent, but rather than admit their crime they cover it up by putting a pitchfork in the dead man's hand and arguing self-defense. Of course, this is really where the story begins...the men start seeing scarecrows near their homes or where they work. At first they suspect the DA is trying to rattle them, or maybe Bubba's grieving mother is taking her revenge. Their paranoia grows as a mysterious accident takes the life of one of their number, and by the end they have turned on each other and Bubba has his revenge....You never really see the monster in this movie until the very end, and barely a drop of blood is spilled throughout. What makes this movie is the competent acting and above-par character development. All of the central characters have somewhat more layers than the typical cannon-fodder found in this genre. Otis in particular makes an interesting small-town villain.

reviewText: So it finally comes out!  Man, I hadn't seen this one since I was a kid! Go figure, it's actually a good film, therefore it never plays on television anymore.  After all we gotta make room for Hardcore Pawn and Steven Seagal:Lawman, right?Yes, Dark Night of the Scarecrow is a made for television movie, therefore it's absent of any nudity, gore or foul language, and guess what?  It's not needed.  Oh, we hardcore horror fans love those things, but we also love a good story and have respect for any good horror film regardless of what year it was made, the rating it got, or the format for which it was made.Dark Night stars Charles Durning as the local postmaster, who has some serious issues with the "village idiot", Bubba(played by Dr. Giggles himself, Larry Drake) hanging out with the local children.  When Bubba's best friend, young Marylee, is attacked by a vicious dog, everyone naturally blames Bubba.  In true postmaster tradition, Durning gets three goons together for an ol' fashioned lynching.  Bubba hides out inside the body of a scarecrow, but is found and the lynchers shoot him dead on the spot.  The law proves useless and Durning and his goons get off without so much as a slap on the wrist.  The D.A. swears justice will be done, but it's not to be, so now it's time to go into full on Bronson mode.Each of the men involved in the lynching end up dying in a series of "accidents", each proceeded by the appearance of the scarecrow hanging in their field.  Durning snoops around trying to find the culprit coz he doesn't believe in supernatural mumbo jumbo.  He suspects the D.A. and even Bubba's mother, and drives himself nearly mad trying to figure it all out.  Things come to a head when he tries to get the truth from little Marylee, who keeps claiming that Bubba is back and talking to her.  Is Bubba really back from the grave?  I'm sure as hell not gonna tell you, so you'd better check it out for yourself.Dark Night of the Scarecrow is a very well written, creepy and fun little horror flick.  It's not gonna scare the crap out of you as reviews tend to say(then again, what really does scare us anymore?), but the film has some great chilling atmosphere and a few suspenseful scenes.  Modern film makers should take a lesson or two instead of bombarding us with torture and gore.  This film definitely falls into the "they don't make em like this anymore" category.  And it's certainly okay for youngsters as well.Not much here other than a commentary, but the restoration job is great.I recently had the pleasure of meeting screenwriter J.D. Feigelson(yeah, I'm bragging), and he remains quite proud of this film.  He should.

reviewText: Can you believe that "Dark Night of the Scarecrow" was a tv movie that came out in 1981? Since then its been rediscovered by millions of cable viewers at Halloween. The movie is set in a small rural town. Its a tale of prejudice and hatred and how it destroys lives. The movie stars Charles Durning as a hate-filled,child-molesting mailman named Otis Hazelrigg. Otis hates the town retard Bubba(Larry Drake) a 36 year old mentally handicapped man who loves to play with children. Otis convinces his three friends that Bubba is dangerous. When a little girl that Bubba has been playing with gets attacked by a dog, the town immediately blames Bubba. Otis and his gang form a lynch mob to track down Bubba. They find him hiding in a scarecrow in a field and promplty execute him by firing squad. Unfortunately they get a call seconds later informing them that the little girl is ok and that Bubba actually saved her life. The men stand trial for their crime but are let off for lack of evidence. Bubba's mother(Jocelyn Brando, Marlon's sister!) warns Otis that "there's other justice in this world". From then on weird things start to happen. Otis and his friends start seeing the scarecrow everywhere and one by one they start getting picked off by strange "accidents". "Dark Night" is an amazing movie. It has a great plot with some great acting by Durning and really the entire cast. Everyone in this movie fits their parts to a tee. It is simply a great story turned into a terrific movie. Everything in this movie clicks, it is indeed a rare and superb movie. It will probably be around for a long time because the movie stands up to multiple watchings. I highly recommend this film to anyone looking for a great movie.

reviewText: I purchased this movie for a friend from the Amazon market place seller and was holding my breath waiting to see what kind of shape a movie this old would be in when it arrived in my mailbox but to my surprise, it arrived in near mint condition.  So my friend, who doesn't live near me, asked me to view the movie to make sure it was okay, I said "sure why not?, I hadn't seen it since it aired on TV, I'll give it a whirl!".Well, in went the tape and aside from some tracking issues, which were solved with tracking controls, during the opening credits?, the movie played flawlessly in my VCR.This is the story of Bubba, who was severely retarded, who befriended one of the local town girls of, shall we say, not of Bubba's physical age but anyways, some of the local townsfolk don't take a liking to Bubba hanging around with little girls and are just looking for any excuse in the world to come down on Bubba like a pack of wild dogs, well, they get their wish, as bubba's friend decides to tresspass in the yard of one of the locals, what she doesn't know is a vicious dog is waiting for her, Bubba crashes through the fence and the scene cuts to the little girls house, where there is a knock on the door, the mother answers the door and sees Bubba standing there with a seemingly lifeless body of her little girl, she lets out a scream and immediately, we see the local "pack of wild dogs" assembling for the hunt. we fast forward a bit when the posse comes to Bubba's house but his mother aint telling nobody nothing, seems they were after Bubba once before but couldn't find him but this time, they bring dogs with them....their search takes them out to the field where they encounter a scarecrow and the mailman (played by Charles Durning), discovers why they didn't find Bubba the first time.............he's hiding in the scarecrow...the last words he utters are "Bubba didn't do nothing"........the Posse opens fire and kills...err executes him but right after they kill him, they find out they executed an innocent man because the sheriff informs them that the little girl is still alive and Bubba saved her from the dog......the Mailman gives you an "Uh Oh" look on his face and I'm ending my review right here, you can either guess the rest or order the movie yourselves but it is a good movie from a TV movie standpoint, well as good as it could be, as old as it, is back when these kinds of movies were on TV but they have graciously omitted commercials.......Thank God.
summary: It aint right executing a mentally challenged man named Bubba!
